content.description: Make just two moves to the left, and you are 30' off the ground!  From the base of the big crack that splits the S side of Pine Tree Rock, traverse left 15', then climb the schist for 20'.  Traverse left, then up (5.10 crux) on small holds to the base of the pillar on the SW side of the face.  Start climbing the pillar, and then decide if you want to GRADUATE, using the 5.8 finish up and left, or SERVE DETENTION and finish on the very steep 5.11 face above!  As with the other two routes on this face, you get a lot of variety!
content.protection: 6 bolts and a couple medium cams for the 5.8 finish.  10 bolts to do the the 5.11 finish.  Both to a double-bolt anchor.
content.location: Summer School starts at the base of the prominent crack that splits the center of the S side of Pine Tree Rock.  From the top, either rappel 80' to the ground (the birch tree is a problem), or carefully down-climb the gully on the E side of P.T.R.  Another option is bring a 2nd rope, and make the 140' rappel down Evergreen on the W side.

content.description: Start this climb up on the ledge behind Shrub and to the left of Evergreen.  Thin crux.
content.location: 30 feet to the left of Evergreen.  Scramble up the ledge to the start.

content.description: This route you can either start by pulling the roof of traverse in from the left and climb the left bolted line. Great holds all the why up.
content.location: When you get to pine tree rock there is a tree right next to the roof or you can boulder up in little valley and traverse in from the left. Bring 2 ropes to rappel down or you can boulder down from the back but its quite steep, I would recommend rapping down.

climbs.name: Emergency Snow Route
climbs.fa: Equipped and first lead, Dave Rone. First onsight, Jim Slichter.

content.description: The route is slightly overhanging for the first 35', so you might get a wee bit of a pump.  But the holds through the schist are real positive!  The crux is some steep reachy moves above the schist, moving into and up left out of a shallow pod about half-way.  The route has lots of fun moves on great holds, with excellent pro.  The original 5.9 rating may be a little soft.  The name comes from a massive snow storm on 6/9/95 that delayed it's creation for a few days!
content.protection: 9 bolts to a double-bolt lowering/rap anchor.
content.location: Emergency Snow Route is the on the SE corner of Pine Tree Rock.  It is the rightmost of the three routes on the south side.

content.description:
Shares a start with Evergreen. Scramble up the boulder and traverse in from the left. Clip the first and second bolts of Evergreen. Use extended slings to reduce rope drag. Veer right, following the bolt line up the slab to the top. 

  Long route. A 70m rope barely gets you to the ground.
content.location: On the NW side of Pine Tree Rock. Bolted route right of Evergreen.

content.description: This route has it all;  overhanging schist, steep crystals and knobs, friction, jams, excellent pro, nice rests, all finished off with a SWEET 5.10 offwidth!  The route starts just to the right of the prominent crack that splits the south face of Pine Tree Rock.  Crux is pulling the bulge half way up.  By the way, you can finish the offwidth a couple different ways.  Either crawl inside for a true offwidth experience, or jam the crack and work your feet up on the outside.
content.protection: 8 bolts to double chain anchors.  Bring a fist-size cam to protect the last 15'

content.description: Pine Tree Rock is home to several moderate to hard, well-protected sport routes;(all L to R) Kiss My Aspen .10+, Evergreen .9, and Ate One Today .10b, on the W side. Summer School .10+ or .11(var), Bruiser .11-, and Emergency Snow Route .9, are on the SW side.  All routes have rappel/lowering anchors on top.
